questions.text: Which is the marked structure amongst the following ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eustachian tube The marked structure is behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate It is the opening of eustachian tube

Highyeild:

Endoscopic view of nasopharynx: IT - Inferior turbinate ET - Eustachian tube TT - Torus tubaris RF - Fossa of Rosenmuller NS - Nasal septum Mucosal end of Eustachian tube opening is seen in the nasopharynx behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Odontoid Option: C. Sphenopalatine foramen Option: D. Agger nasi None of the above structures are seen on endoscopic view of nasopharynx

questions.text: Identify the fracture in the given diagram:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chevallet fracture The image shows a vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine region towards the dorsum of nose This type of fracture is known as Chevallet fracture

Highyeild:

Nasal septum fractures: Jarjaway fracture It results from blows from the front; It starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer Chevallet fracture It results from blows from below; It runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of bony and cartilaginous dorsum of nose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Jarjaway fracture-It is a horizontal fracture of the nasal septum above the anterior nasal spine which runs horizontally backwards Option: C. Le Fort 1-fracture runs above and parallel to the palate. It crosses lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates. Option: D. Simple fracture-It has no specific definition

Table:

#MANTRA Le fort fractures:

questions.text: Which of the following is life threatening nerve injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilateral Complete RLN Palsy Amongst the given options, bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis is life threatening As all the intrinsic muscles are paralysed, the vocal cords are in median or paramedical position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles Due to this there is dyspnoea and stridor

Highyeild:

Bilateral (Bilateral Abductor Paralysis) Aetiology-Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. Position of Cords-As all the intrinsic muscles of larynx are paralyzed, the vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles As both the cords lie in median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good. Dyspnoea and stridor become worse on exertion Treatment: Tracheostomy Airway widening techniques: arytenoidectomy with suture, (ii) arytenoidopexy (fixing the arytenoid in lateral position), (iii) lateralization of vocal cord and (iv) laser cordectomy (removal of one cord) Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation). Partial arytenoidectomy. Reinnervation procedures. Thyroplasty type II.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Bilateral Partial RLN palsy Option: C. Unilateral complete RLN palsy Option: D. Unilateral partial RLN palsy The above given options are not life threatening

Table:

#MANTRA Laryngeal nerve paralysis: Incomplete/Abductor palsy Complete/Abductor palsy U/L RLN palsy B/L RLN palsy U/L B/L Speech Normal/Slight hoarseness Normal Dysphonia/Aphonia Aphonia Respiration Normal Stridor Normal Normal Aspiration Absent Absent Occasional Chronic aspiration Management Conservative Tracheostomy and lateralisation of one vocal cord Medialisation of vocal cord Tracheostomy and epiglottopexy

questions.text: Croup can be caused by the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Para Influenza Croup is also known as acute laryngotracheobronchitis It is caused by Parainfluenza virus types I and II

Highyeild:

Croup (laryngotracheitis and laryngotracheobronchitis): It is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea and bronchi; more common than acute epiglottitis. Aetiology: Viral infection (parainfluenza type I and II) affecting children between 6 months and 3 years of age. Male > Female. Secondary bacterial infection by Gram-positive cocci soon supervenes. Pathology : The loose areolar tissue in the subglottic region swells up and causes respiratory obstruction and stridor. If coupled with thick tenacious secretions and crusts, may completely occlude the airway. Symptoms: Presents as upper respiratory infection with hoarseness and croupy/barking cough. Fever of 39–40 °C. Difficulty in breathing and inspiratory/biphasic type of stridor. Management: Once the diagnosis of croup is made, mist therapy, corticosteroids and epinephrine are the usual treatments. Since croup is chiefly viral in etiology, antibiotics play no role. Mist therapy (warm or cool) is thought to reduce the severity of croup by moistening the mucosa and reducing the viscosity of exudates, making coughing more productive. For patients with mild symptoms, mist therapy will suffice For more severe cases, further intervention may be required like oxygen inhalation by mask, racemic epinephrine given by nebulizer, corticosteroids and intubation or tracheostomy.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Streptococcus Option: B. Haemophilus Influenza Option: D. N Gonorrhoea These are not the cause for croup

Table:

#MANTRA Differences Between Acute Epiglottitis and Acute Laryngo-Tracheo-Bronchitis in Children: Acute epiglottitis Acute laryngotracheobronchitis s (or croup) Causative organism Haemophilus influenzae type B Parainfluenza virus type I and II Age 2-7 years 3 months to 3 years Pathology Supraglottic larynx Subglottic area Prodromal symptoms Absent Present Onset Sudden Slow Fever High Low grade or no fever Patient's look Toxic Nontoxic Cough Usually absent Present (barking seal- like Stridor Present and may be marked Present Odynophagia Present, with drooling of secretions Usually absent Radiology *Thumb sign on lateral view Steeple sign on anteroposterior view of neck Treatment Humidified oxygen, third generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone) or amoxicillin Humidified O 2 tent, steroids

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the following PTA conducted on a patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mixed hearing loss X indicates AC and > indicates bone conduction In the given audiogram, both air conduction and bone conduction curves are well below the normal hearing level Hence, it is mixed type of hearing loss

Highyeild:

Conductive Hearing Loss Audiometry shows bone conduction better than air conduction with air-bone gap. Greater the air-bone gap, more is the conductive loss Sensorineural Hearing Loss: No gap between air and bone conduction curve on audiometry

Table:

#MANTRA Audiogram showing Noise induced hearing loss with a dip at 4000 Hz

questions.text: Carhart's notch seen in which of the following condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Otosclerosis It is a depression in bone conduction curve seen in pure tone audiometry It is seen in cases of otosclerosis

Highyeild:

Carhart’s notch: The Carhart notch (CN) is a depression in the bone-conduction audiogram of patients with clinical otosclerosis The increase in BC thresholds for otosclerosis, maximal at 2 kHz, is called the “Carhart notch Otosclerosis left ear. Note dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction (Carhart's notch). Fig - Carhart’s notch If the BC curve shows a notch which is duplicated on the air conduction (AC) curve; this AC-notch is usually called a “cookie bite”

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Ossicular Discontinuity Option: C. Meniere's / Oto syphilis Option: D. Serous otitis media Carhart’s notch is seen in otosclerosis and not any of the above options

Table:

#MANTRA Selection of Patients for Stapes Surgery: Hearing threshold for air conduction should be 30 dB or worse. Average air-bone gap should be at least 15 dB with Rinne negative for 256 and 512 Hz. Speech discrimination score should be 60% or more.

questions.text: Which one of the following causes maximum hearing loss:

options.label: B
options.text: Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disrupted ossicular chain with intact tympanic membrane Amongst the given options, maximum hearing loss is seen in disrupted ossicles chain with intact tympanic membrane Hearing loss in such cases is around 54dB

Highyeild:

Average Hearing Loss Seen in Different Lesions of Conductive Apparatus: Complete obstruction of ear canal 30 db Perforation of tympanic membrane (It varies and is directly proportional to the size of perforation) 10-40 db Ossicular interruption with intact drum 54 db Ossicular interruption with perforation 38 db Malleus fixation 10-25 db Closure of oval window 60 db Tympanogram type Ad is seen in ossicular discontinuity

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Serous otitis media-In this, there is conductive hearing loss is around 20-40dB Option: C. Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane-Here, it is around 38dB Option: D. Partial footplate fixation-This has hearing loss which is different at different frequencies. Carhart’s notch is seen at 2000Hz in BC curve

Table:

#MANTRA Types of tympanograms: Type A Normal tympanogram. Type As Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in fixation of ossicles, e.g. otosclerosis or malleus fixation. Type Ad High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity or thin and lax tympanic membrane. Type B A flat or dome-shaped graph. No change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane. Type C Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure in excess of 100 mm H2O. Seen in retracted tympanic membrane and may show some fluid in middle ear. Fig - Types of tympanogram

questions.text: Most common hearing test done in neonate for screening:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

OAE OAE is the test commonly used for screening of hearing in neonates To test hearing in uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals after sedation

Highyeild:

Neonatal/Infantile Hearing Screening for hearing loss: The American Academy of Pediatrics aims for universal detection of hearing loss in infants before 3 months of age, so that appropriate intervention can be done at less than 6 months of age. The recommended hearing screening techniques are either otoacoustic emissions (OAE) testing or auditory brainstem evoked responses (ABRs). OAE testing israpid, easy to administer, inexpensive, and sensitive. It is therefore used for initial screening. Results of OAE are relatively easy to interpret. If hearing loss of more than 30-40 dB is present, OAE testing gives no response. If OAE shows no response, ABR is done as a confirmatory test. ABR test is an auditory evoked electrophysiologic response, that correlate highly with hearing. Screening methods such as observing behavioural responses to sound such as the cribogram or the auditory response cradle are not recommended

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Clap & Smile- Clap can be used in children of 6 - 7 months of age Option: B. BERA-It is used in infants Option: D. PTA-It is used in adults
